    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-138128-_zdjjbbl29xlf"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>We identified a cluster of activity that we track as <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/from-activity-to-formal-naming/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CL-STA-0048</a>. This cluster targeted high-value targets in South Asia, including a telecommunications organization.</p>
<p>This activity cluster used rare tools and techniques including the technique we call Hex Staging, in which the attackers deliver payloads in chunks. Their activity also includes exfiltration over DNS using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ping</span>, and abusing the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/tools/sqlcmd/sqlcmd-utility?view=sql-server-ver16&amp;tabs=go%2Cwindows" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SQLcmd</a> utility for data theft.</p>
<p>Based on an analysis of the tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs), as well as the tools used, the infrastructure and the victimology, we assess with moderate-high confidence that this activity originates in China.</p>
<p>The campaign primarily aimed to obtain the personal information of government employees and steal sensitive data from targeted organizations. These objectives bear the hallmarks of a nation-state advanced persistent threat (APT) espionage operation.</p>
<p>The threat actor behind this campaign demonstrated a methodical approach to network penetration to establish a foothold. We observed systematic attempts to exploit known vulnerabilities on public-facing servers, specifically targeting the following services:</p>
<ul>
<li>IIS</li>
<li>Apache Tomcat</li>
<li>MSSQL services</li>
</ul>
<p>Organizations that protect sensitive information should focus on patching commonly exploited vulnerabilities. They should also follow best practices for IT hygiene, as APTs frequently attempt to gain access using methods that have proven successful in the past.</p>
<p>We are sharing our analysis to provide defenders with means to detect and protect themselves against such advanced attacks.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/infographics/xsiam-product-tour?utm_source=google-jg-amer-cortex-socf-siam&amp;utm_medium=paid_search&amp;utm_campaign=google-cortex-xsiam-amer-multi-awareness-en-eg-non_brand-broad&amp;utm_content=7014u000001eDtMAAU&amp;utm_term=siem%20integration&amp;cq_plac=&amp;cq_net=g&amp;gad_source=1&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI9sLv--faiAMVVnFHAR1IcyvDEAAYASAAEgJ8VPD_BwE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a>.</p>
<p>Customers are also better protected through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a> for the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a>, including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a>, <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a>.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XPANSE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> provides proactive detection of potential adversary entry points</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/china/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>China</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cobalt-strike/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cobalt Strike</a></strong>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/data-exfiltration/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Data Exfiltration</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_gdcph0px9i8r"></a><strong>Timeline of Activity</strong></h2>
<p>Throughout our investigation, we observed a distinct sequence of events that characterized the threat actor's activities. Figure 1 illustrates this timeline, showcasing the key stages and progression of the attack.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138131" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138131" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138131 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-322777-138128-1.png" alt="Timeline diagram titled 'CL-STA-0048 Timeline' detailing various cybersecurity events from May 2024 to November 2024, including tasks like 'IIS Server Exploit Attempt' and 'User Creation Apache' along with others related to SQL injection, credential theft, and server access. There are five points in the series. " width="1000" height="599" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-322777-138128-1.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-322777-138128-1-734x440.png 734w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-322777-138128-1-1168x700.png 1168w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-322777-138128-1-768x460.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-322777-138128-1-1536x920.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138131" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Activity timeline of CL-STA-0048.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_510pg4a3d1wc"></a><strong>Exploiting Multiple Entry Points</strong></h2>
<p>We observed the threat actor attempting to exploit three critical services, one after the other:</p>
<ul>
<li>IIS</li>
<li>Apache Tomcat</li>
<li>MSSQL Services</li>
</ul>
<p>With each failure, the threat actor adapted, targeting the next vulnerable asset in this list.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_dx80qivtl7bt"></a>The Initial Target: Attempting to Exploit IIS Servers</h3>
<p>On the first attempt, the threat actor tried to exploit vulnerabilities on multiple IIS servers in the environment, trying to deliver and deploy several web shells. These attempts were blocked by Cortex XDR.</p>
<h3>Anti-Webshell and Anti-Exploitation Modules</h3>
<p>The attackers’ attempts to deploy a web shell were also prevented by Cortex XDR.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_6e3pwbtojnh3"></a>The Attackers Shift to Apache Tomcat</h3>
<p>After failing to exploit the IIS servers, the threat actor targeted an internet-facing Apache server, deploying a <a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-339a" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ColdFusion</a> web shell as shown in Figure 2. This was again blocked by Cortex XDR.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138133" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138133" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138133 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-326622-138128-2.png" alt="Screenshot of code with attributes and tags like 'Form.Action', 'FileContents', and 'uploadcss', aimed at handling file uploads and form submissions, viewed in a code editor with a dark background and color-coded text." width="700" height="192" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-326622-138128-2.png 1042w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-326622-138128-2-786x216.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-326622-138128-2-768x211.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138133" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. ColdFusion web shell used in the attack.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_1lfi6pykasnr"></a>One Final Attempt: An MSSQL Server</h3>
<p>On the third attempt, the threat actor was able to compromise an unpatched internet-facing MSSQL server. The following section details the malicious activity that we observed from the compromised server.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_r8gynv73gtze"></a><strong>Reconnaissance and a Rarely Seen Exfiltration Technique</strong></h2>
<p>The threat actor leveraged PowerShell to download multiple batch scripts from a remote server. These scripts executed commands such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tasklist</span> to enumerate running processes on compromised machines and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dir</span> to list the contents of directories.</p>
<p>The scripts exfiltrated command outputs by formatting each line as a string constructed of a series of subdomains and sending <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ping</span> requests to these subdomains. Each <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ping</span> command triggered a DNS request, transmitting the exfiltrated data to the attackers via DNS.</p>
<p>The threat actor used <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dnslog.pw</span>, a Chinese DNS logging tool for pen testers, to capture the output. Figure 3 below illustrates this data exfiltration technique.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138135" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138135" style="width: 931px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138135 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-329289-138128-3.png" alt="Process tree in Cortex XDR showing a network of processes. The processes are visually connected by lines, indicating interactions and data flows, with numerical annotations and icons representing different statuses or functions. Some text and elements are blurred for privacy." width="931" height="623" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-329289-138128-3.png 931w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-329289-138128-3-658x440.png 658w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-329289-138128-3-768x514.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 931px) 100vw, 931px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138135" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Process tree of the data exfiltration using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ping</span> command.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In addition, the threat actor attempted to save the output of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dir</span> command into text files and then uploaded the output file to their command and control (C2) server using PowerShell. Figure 4 below shows the command they used.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138137" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138137" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138137 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-331996-138128-4.png" alt="Text showing command line instructions for the exfiltration." width="700" height="114" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-331996-138128-4.png 1114w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-331996-138128-4-786x128.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-331996-138128-4-768x125.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138137" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Exfiltration command.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_f79nkx9tnmj6"></a><strong>Preparing the Ground: The “Hex Staging” Method and Delivering Malware</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_wb9tu2ltz65l"></a>PlugX as the Attacker's Main Backdoor</h3>
<p>The initial and primary backdoor the threat actor used in this attack was the <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PlugX</a> backdoor. PlugX is a well-known remote access tool (RAT) with modular plugins and customizable settings that has been popular for over a decade, primarily among <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/plugx-variants-in-usbs/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chinese-speaking threat groups</a>.</p>
<p>The threat actor abused <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">certutil</span> to download the PlugX component from a remote domain under the following URL path:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">https://h5.nasa6[.]com/shell/</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The attackers dropped and executed the following payloads:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Acrobat.exe</span> - A legitimate Adobe Acrobat binary</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Acrobat.dxe</span> - An encrypted PlugX payload</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Acrobat.dll</span> - A PlugX loader</li>
</ul>
<p>The payloads were saved under the path <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\DSSM\</span></p>
<p>The threat actor then used the <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/002/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DLL sideloading technique</a> and exploited vulnerable legitimate binaries (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Acrobat.exe</span>) to initiate the PlugX loader <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Acrobat.dll</span>. This <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/dll-hijacking-techniques/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">technique</a> was detected by Cortex XDR.</p>
<p>When the legitimate binary successfully sideloaded the PlugX loader, it searched for the payload <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Acrobat.dxe</span> in the system. Once it found the payload, the PlugX loader proceeded to load, decrypt and then inject it into a legitimate instance of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">svchost.exe</span>.</p>
<p>The PlugX payload then connected to the C2 server <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mail.tttseo[.]com</span>, executing in memory as a detection evasion attempt.</p>
<p>Talos mentioned similar TTPs including the same file names, several hashes and the C2 address in their September 2024 blog about a Chinese threat actor called <a href="https://blog.talosintelligence.com/dragon-rank-seo-poisoning/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DragonRank</a>. Figure 5 shows how Cortex XDR captured the PlugX execution flow.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138139" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138139" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138139 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-334521-138128-5.png" alt="Cortex XDR network security alert interface showing two warnings with associated process details, displaying IP addresses and module paths. Some information is redacted. " width="800" height="322" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-334521-138128-5.png 1099w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-334521-138128-5-786x317.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-334521-138128-5-768x310.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138139" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Detection of PlugX execution flow, as shown in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_nylvxrqaj1ir"></a>Hex Staging: Another Rarely Seen Technique Used by the Threat Actor</h3>
<p>Once the threat actor gained a foothold inside the network, they attempted to upload additional tools. They employed a stealthy and uncommon technique to do this, in which the attackers deliver payloads in chunks (<a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">T1027: Obfuscated Files or Information)</a>. We call this technique Hex Staging.</p>
<p>In Hex Staging, an attacker incrementally writes hex-encoded data into a temporary file piece by piece, using commands passed to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe</span>. This method avoids detection systems that scan for direct file writes.</p>
<p>Once the file is assembled in hex format, the attacker uses a tool like <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">certutil</span> to decode the hex data back into ASCII. This content could be either binary executables or scripts. This method bypasses conventional security detection by using native Windows utilities to covertly deliver and execute malicious code.</p>
<p>Figure 6 shows an example of the Hex Staging commands used by the threat actor.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138141" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138141" style="width: 1054px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138141 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-337833-138128-6.png" alt="Screenshot of a table in Cortex XDR with an MZ header highlighted." width="1054" height="511" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-337833-138128-6.png 1054w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-337833-138128-6-786x381.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-337833-138128-6-768x372.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1054px) 100vw, 1054px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138141" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Hex Staging commands.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The threat actor attempted to deliver multiple files using this method. This included binary files such as Cobalt Strike loaders and implants, as well as a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.sql</span> script, which we will describe later in this post.</p>
<p>A PowerShell script that loaded Cobalt Strike (shown in Figure 7) was among the payloads they wrote using that technique. It was detected and prevented by Cortex XDR.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138143" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138143" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138143 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-340634-138128-7.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer screen displaying complex programming code in an IDE with syntax highlighting, involving functions and system calls." width="1000" height="353" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-340634-138128-7.png 1911w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-340634-138128-7-786x277.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-340634-138128-7-768x271.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-340634-138128-7-1536x542.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138143" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Alert for the malicious PowerShell script, as shown in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_5w7ohooadgdc"></a>Privilege Escalation Tools</h3>
<h4><a id="post-138128-_gbli6cx3ji48"></a>SspiUacBypass</h4>
<p>After establishing a foothold in the environment, we observed the threat actor attempting to bypass User Account Control (UAC), leveraging the <a href="https://github.com/antonioCoco/SspiUacBypass" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SspiUacBypass</a> tool. This technique exploits the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/security/windows-authentication/security-support-provider-interface-architecture" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Windows Security Support Provider Interface (SSPI)</a> to sidestep UAC prompts, allowing the actor to run high-privileged processes without user consent.</p>
<h4><a id="post-138128-_himfqngyx6lb"></a>The Potato Suite</h4>
<p>To successfully execute certain tools, the threat actors needed to run their tools and commands with adequate privileges, such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Admin</span> or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SYSTEM</span>. To do so, they used different tools from the popular Potato Suite, a collection of various native Windows privilege escalation tools.</p>
<p>The main tools that we observed during the investigation were:</p>
<ul>
<li>BadPotato: A local privilege escalation tool that elevates user privileges to SYSTEM for command execution</li>
<li>RasmanPotato: This tool exploits the Windows <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/rdcman" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Remote Access Connection Manager</a> (RASMAN) service to gain system-level access, allowing high-privilege operations without user interaction</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_khw6h04wdaqo"></a>Command-and-Control Tools</h3>
<h4><a id="post-138128-_w9fckae1u561"></a>SoftEther VPN</h4>
<p>Another tool that we observed the threat actor using is a renamed version of the open-source SoftEther VPN. This software is flexible and has multi-protocol support. Threat actors, <a href="https://www.welivesecurity.com/en/eset-research/eset-apt-activity-report-q2-2024-q3-2024/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">particularly those in Chinese groups</a>, frequently abuse it for stealthy communications and bypassing network restrictions.</p>
<p>Figure 8 shows the command the threat actors used to download the client and configuration file.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138145" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138145" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138145 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-344839-138128-8.png" alt="Screenshot showing two Command Prompt inputs executing commands with parameters that include URLs and file paths related to the FortiEDR software." width="700" height="164" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-344839-138128-8.png 898w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-344839-138128-8-786x184.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-344839-138128-8-768x180.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138145" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. The command used to download the SoftEther VPN client and configuration file.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-138128-_teozqef21yu6"></a>Winos4.0-Based Downloader</h4>
<p>The threat actor also attempted to use a downloader built using the advanced malicious framework <a href="https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hackers-increasingly-use-winos40-post-exploitation-kit-in-attacks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Winos4.0</a>. The downloader, placed under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">drivers\etc</span> masquerading as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hosts.exe</span>, attempted to connect to the IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">154.201.68[.]57</span>.</p>
<p>After a successful connection, it downloads the payload and saves it into the registry key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d33f351a4aeea5e608853d1a56661059</span>. It then executes the payload. Fortinet observed similar behavior as part of the execution of another malware called <a href="https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/valleyrat-campaign-targeting-chinese-speakers" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ValleyRAT</a>, which we believe the threat actor built using the same framework.</p>
<p>The downloader variant we discovered also leverages the <a href="https://github.com/skywind3000/kcp" target="_blank" rel="noopener">KCP Protocol</a>. This is a fast and reliable <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_repeat_request" target="_blank" rel="noopener">automatic repeat-request</a> (ARQ) protocol that provides low-latency and faster communications.</p>
<p>Chinese threat actors were the <a href="https://www.virusbulletin.com/uploads/pdf/conference/vb2023/papers/Lets-go-door-with-KCP.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">main users of this protocol [PDF]</a> in the past, including the infamous <a href="https://global.ptsecurity.com/analytics/pt-esc-threat-intelligence/higaisa-or-winnti-apt-41-backdoors-old-and-new" target="_blank" rel="noopener">APT41</a>. This corresponds with the fact that the main GitHub page is written in Mandarin, suggesting it mainly addresses Mandarin-speaking hackers.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_p7ypg8q6mtsn"></a><strong>Cobalt Strike Execution</strong></h2>
<p>The threat actor deployed Cobalt Strike to execute additional malicious activities within the compromised environment. Using the Hex Staging technique mentioned earlier, the loader was dropped onto the SQL server. Upon execution, it injected the Cobalt Strike beacon into <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">winlogon.exe</span>, initiating communication with the configured C2 server <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sentinelones[.]com</span>.</p>
<p>One of their initial objectives was dumping the LSASS process. This attempt was detected and successfully blocked by Cortex XDR, preventing the harvesting of credentials.</p>
<p>The threat actor also used the Cobalt Strike implant to deliver additional payloads. Those payloads were two sets of legitimate binaries and DLLs:</p>
<ul>
<li>The first pair was a legitimate <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ecmd.exe</span> and the malicious DLL <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">msvcp140.dll</span></li>
<li>The second pair was the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AppLaunch.exe</span> application and the malicious DLL <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mscoree.dll</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The threat sideloaded the malicious DLLs to the legitimate binaries to load <a href="https://github.com/ph4ntonn/Stowaway/blob/master/README_EN.md" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Stowaway</a>, a multi-hop proxy tool, shown in Figure 9 below. The threat actor used this tool to create a connection back to one of its main C2 servers: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">43.247.135[.]106</span>.</p>
<p>After failing to load the malicious DLLs, the threat actor tried to use another tool for the same purpose: <a href="https://github.com/EddieIvan01/iox" target="_blank" rel="noopener">iox</a>, a port forward and intranet proxy tool.</p>
<p>Finally, the actor attempted to create a new database user through the Cobalt Strike beacon. We will explore this step and its implications in detail in the <a href="#post-138128-_179f1fh0662z">following section</a>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138147" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138147" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138147 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-347562-138128-9.png" alt="Cortex XDR process tree showing a cyber attack sequence, with numbered steps indicating the progression of processes and interactions between files and commands, including connections to IP addresses." width="1000" height="797" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-347562-138128-9.png 1223w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-347562-138128-9-552x440.png 552w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-347562-138128-9-878x700.png 878w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-347562-138128-9-768x612.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138147" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Execution flow of Cobalt Strike, as shown in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_179f1fh0662z"></a><strong>Aiming Toward the Database: Stealing Tables Data</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_5pn8xosfy3qy"></a>Creating a Privileged Database User</h3>
<p>Once the threat actor established their presence in the network, they attempted to exfiltrate sensitive data from SQL servers.</p>
<p>The threat actor initially attempted to create a database user with the username <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webuseraa</span> and password <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">teasd$%!FFr</span>. They granted the user System Administrator privileges on the main database using the command shown in Figure 10.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138149" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138149" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138149 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-350792-138128-10.png" alt="Command prompt screenshot showing the execution of SQL commands to create a login named 'newuseraa' with a specified password and adding this user to the 'sysadmin' role on a Microsoft SQL server." width="700" height="86" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-350792-138128-10.png 1010w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-350792-138128-10-786x96.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-350792-138128-10-768x94.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138149" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Creation of database user.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_7o1mz1ei2xip"></a>Deploying a Malicious SQL Script</h3>
<p>The attacker also created an SQL script named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1.sql.tmp</span> using the Hex Staging technique mentioned earlier in this post. They first decoded the hex file into ASCII using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">certutil</span> and saved the file as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1.sql</span> (shown in Figure 11).</p>
<figure id="attachment_138151" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138151" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138151 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-354076-138128-11.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer screen displaying a complex SQL query code on a dark background with light text." width="1000" height="406" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-354076-138128-11.png 1356w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-354076-138128-11-786x319.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-354076-138128-11-768x312.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138151" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. The malicious SQL script.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Then they executed the script and saved the output into the text file shown in Figure 12 below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138153" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138153" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138153 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-357116-138128-12.png" alt="Screenshot displaying a command line interface with a typed command that includes a file path pointing to the &quot;cmd.exe&quot; in the Windows System32 directory." width="800" height="63" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-357116-138128-12.png 1070w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-357116-138128-12-786x62.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-357116-138128-12-768x60.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138153" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Execution of the malicious SQL script.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This script identifies and exfiltrates sensitive contact information stored across multiple databases by searching for columns that could contain phone-related data, such as those named “phone,” “Mobile” or “TEL.” The script then aggregates results across databases, generating a list with the database name, schema, table, column names and total row count for each match.</p>
<p>Figure 13 shows the execution flow of the SQL script.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138155" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138155" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138155 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-359581-138128-13.png" alt="Cortex XDR process tree depicting various CMD command lines involving system tasks. The flow starts from a single point on the left, expanding into multiple branches." width="1000" height="848" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-359581-138128-13.png 1174w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-359581-138128-13-519x440.png 519w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-359581-138128-13-825x700.png 825w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-359581-138128-13-768x652.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138155" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Execution flow of the SQL script, as shown in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After executing the script, the threat actor attempted to exfiltrate the output text file containing the results to their C2 server, as shown in Figure 14. They then deleted the script from the server.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138157" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138157" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138157 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-362778-138128-14.png" alt="Screenshot of text on a computer screen displaying a command line prompt executing a PowerShell script." width="800" height="60" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-362778-138128-14.png 1086w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-362778-138128-14-786x59.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-362778-138128-14-768x58.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138157" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Exfiltration command.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_nyr0p635o05"></a>The Abuse of Sqlcmd.exe for Data Exfiltration</h3>
<p>By leveraging the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/tools/sqlcmd/sqlcmd-utility?view=sql-server-ver16&amp;tabs=go%2Cwindows&amp;pivots=cs1-bash" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sqlcmd</a> utility, the attacker connected to the local SQL server instance (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">127.0.0[.]1</span>) on port 1434 and executed a dynamic SQL query. Such a query creates a temporary table to store metadata about all tables across accessible databases.</p>
<p>The script dynamically generates SQL commands to iterate through all user databases (excluding system databases) and retrieves details like database name, schema name and table name. Figure 15 below shows the database harvesting command.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138159" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138159" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138159 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-365337-138128-15.png" alt="Screenshot showing a command line interface executing a script that interacts with system databases." width="700" height="123" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-365337-138128-15.png 1328w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-365337-138128-15-786x138.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-365337-138128-15-768x135.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138159" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. DB harvesting command-line execution.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The results are then sorted and written into an output file (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\users\public\123.txt</span>), which the threat actors tried to exfiltrate later, as shown in Figure 16 below. After that, the threat actor deleted the temporary table.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138161" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138161" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138161 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-367995-138128-16.png" alt="Screenshot showing a snippet of computer code for exfiltration." width="800" height="53" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-367995-138128-16.png 1089w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-367995-138128-16-786x52.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-367995-138128-16-768x51.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138161" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. Exfiltration command.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Finally, the threat actor attempted to extract personally identifiable information (PII) and sensitive client data from one of the databases, specifically targeting details such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Client names</li>
<li>Mobile numbers</li>
<li>Gender</li>
<li>Birth dates</li>
<li>Email IDs</li>
<li>Residential addresses</li>
</ul>
<p>The command groups this data by mobile number and saves the output as a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> file, as shown in Figure 17.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138163" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138163" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138163 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-370866-138128-17.png" alt="Screenshot displaying a line of SQL code on a dark background with syntax highlighting, showing commands and functions for querying client details from a database." width="800" height="114" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-370866-138128-17.png 1705w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-370866-138128-17-786x112.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-370866-138128-17-768x109.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-370866-138128-17-1536x218.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138163" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. Database theft command-line execution.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_cdnjim4yi8j1"></a><strong>Connection to the Chinese Nexus</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_r7bh3j3djd2f"></a>Overlaps with DragonRank</h3>
<p>The threat actor behind this cluster of activity employed PlugX as one of its primary backdoors. They used specific components (notably the loader and payload), exhibiting an overlap with those used by <a href="https://blog.talosintelligence.com/dragon-rank-seo-poisoning/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DragonRank</a>, a recently identified Chinese threat group.</p>
<p>We lack sufficient data on DragonRank to definitively link it to CL-STA-0048. However, we acknowledge the similarities between the two while keeping CL-STA-0048 as a distinct cluster for tracking purposes. This allows us to monitor for potential connections without making premature conclusions.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_74psqlv7i66x"></a>Activity Time Frame</h3>
<p>During our investigation, we successfully traced the time frame of the threat actor's interactive sessions. We focused on hands-on-keyboard commands executed on the compromised SQL server, as well as commands sent to the different active backdoors. A thorough review of the activity's time over several months revealed a notable and consistent pattern.</p>
<p>Our findings, as illustrated in Figure 18 below, demonstrate a correlation with typical 9-to-5 working hours in the UTC+8 time zone. This time period notably aligns with the business hours of various Asian nations, with China being a prominent example.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138165" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138165" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138165 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-373622-138128-18.png" alt="Dual line chart showing two data sets, plotted over time." width="1000" height="557" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-373622-138128-18.png 1866w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-373622-138128-18-786x438.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-373622-138128-18-1257x700.png 1257w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-373622-138128-18-768x428.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-373622-138128-18-1536x855.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138165" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 18. Comparison of activity time frame between UTC and UTC+8.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_kpws2e85tcgl"></a>DNS Logging Service</h3>
<p>Figure 19 shows that the threat actor used a DNS logging service primarily designed for a Chinese-speaking audience to exfiltrate command output, as we mentioned earlier in this article. Although this service is globally accessible, its usage patterns and associated tool ecosystems suggest a predominant adoption within Chinese cybersecurity circles, where it closely aligns with local security testing practices.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138167" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138167" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138167 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-376694-138128-19.png" alt="Screenshot of a website named DNSlog.pw featuring the DNSlog System. The text is in Chinese and describes the website." width="700" height="155" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-376694-138128-19.png 1246w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-376694-138128-19-786x174.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-376694-138128-19-768x170.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138167" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 19. DNSlog System web description.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_g8uwpig4zx69"></a>KCP Protocol</h3>
<p>The threat actor’s use of a Winos4.0-based Downloader leveraging the KCP Protocol could suggest a Chinese origin. The protocol has been historically associated with Chinese threat actors like APT41 and is documented primarily in Mandarin, indicating its intended audience is Chinese-speaking developers. This linguistic and operational context points to a likely connection to the Chinese cyberthreat ecosystem.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_2crk43r2h0f5"></a>Supershell Panel</h3>
<p>During our investigation, we observed the attackers downloading several files from the IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">206.237.0[.]49</span>. <a href="https://www.elastic.co/security-labs/unmasking-financial-services-intrusion-ref0657" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Elastic</a> disclosed this IP address in January 2024 as part of the Supershell C2 platform. While <a href="https://github.com/tdragon6/Supershell/tree/main" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Supershell</a> is openly available on GitHub, its interface and documentation are primarily tailored to a Mandarin-speaking audience, further solidifying the connection to the Chinese nexus.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_uomlt8uabyk4"></a><strong>Conclusion </strong></h2>
<p>The CL-STA-0048 campaign represents a significant threat, targeting government and telecom entities in South Asia with a clear focus on espionage. The threat actor behind it leverages tactics to evade detection, bypass security measures and exfiltrate sensitive data from high-value targets.</p>
<p>CL-STA-0048 exploits unpatched vulnerabilities in widely used services such as IIS, Apache Tomcat and MSSQL. It adapts to new defenses and deploys rarely seen techniques, adjusting its methods to overcome defenses and achieve its objectives.</p>
<p>Our analysis indicates a strong link between this group and the Chinese nexus based on the observed tools, techniques and victimology.</p>
<p>These findings emphasize the critical need for organizations to prioritize proactive cybersecurity measures. Addressing known vulnerabilities, maintaining robust IT hygiene and employing vigilant threat monitoring are essential to counter adversaries like CL-STA-0048. Organizations can better protect sensitive data and defend against advanced and persistent threats by strengthening security measures and staying informed about emerging threats.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_z5usflbfd2th"></a><strong>Protections and Mitigations</strong></h2>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this activity cluster:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> cloud-delivered malware analysis service accurately identifies the PlugX and CobaltStrike samples mentioned in this article as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify domains associated with this group as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM">XSIAM</a> are designed to:
<ul>
<li>Prevent the execution of known malicious malware and also prevent the execution of unknown malware using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Behavioral Threat Protection and</a> machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.</li>
<li>Protect against exploitation of different vulnerabilities using the <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Pro-Administrator-Guide/Endpoint-Protection-Capabilities" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anti-Exploitation modules</a> as well as Behavioral Threat Protection.</li>
<li>Detect post-exploit activity, including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/techbriefs/cortex-xdr-identity-analytics">credential-based attacks</a>, with behavioral <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Pro-Administrator-Guide/Analytics-Concepts" target="_blank" rel="noopener">analytics</a> through Cortex XDR Pro and XSIAM.</li>
<li>Detect user and credential-based threats by analyzing anomalous user activity from multiple data sources.</li>
<li>Protect from threat actors dropping and executing commands from web shells using Anti-Webshell Protection.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XPANSE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> is able to detect internet-exposed Microsoft IIS, Apache Tomcat and MSSQL Servers, among hundreds of other types of enterprise applications.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 00080005045107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138128-_ydqdbjg0dngh"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_irdcnebdubkk"></a>Cobalt Strike Loaders</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">525540eac2d90c94dd3352c7dd624720ff2119082807e2670785aed77746301d</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">af0baf0a9142973a3b2a6c8813a3b4096e516188a48f7fd26ecc8299bce508e1</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_gq3x79um922p"></a>Cobalt Strike C2</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sentinelones[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-138128-_d1abma362azt"></a>PlugX</h3>
<ul>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0f85b67f0c4ca0e7a80df8567265b3fa9f44f2ad6ae09a7c9b7fac2ca24e62a8</span></li>
</ul>

</ul>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8dfc107662f22cff20d19e0aba76fcd181657255078a78fb1be3d3a54d0c3d46</span></li>

                                          <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/13_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="A pictorial representation of a jailbreaking technique.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:Bad Likert Judge: A Novel Multi-Turn Technique to Jailbreak LLMs by Misusing Their Evaluation Capability:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-31T23:00:16+00:00">December 31, 2024</time></span>

				<li role="listitem">

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of FrostyGoop malware. Close-up view of a digital screen displaying a pixelated, abstract image, possibly representing a face." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-19T11:00:15+00:00">November 19, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/frostygoop-malware-analysis/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications">
                    <h4 class="post-title">FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/bustleberm/" title="BUSTLEBERM" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:BUSTLEBERM">BUSTLEBERM</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/frostygoop/" title="FrostyGoop" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:FrostyGoop">FrostyGoop</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/go/" title="Go" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:Go">Go</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>

            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/05_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of a threat like the Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) technique. Image of computer code on a screen with a prominent biohazard symbol." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/05_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/05_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/05_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/05_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/05_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:TA Phone Home: EDR Evasion Testing Reveals Extortion Actor&#039;s Toolkit:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-01T22:00:12+00:00">November 1, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/edr-bypass-extortion-attempt-thwarted/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="espionage-campaign-targets-south-asian-entities:related-resources:TA Phone Home: EDR Evasion Testing Reveals Extortion Actor&#039;s Toolkit">
                    <h4 class="post-title">TA Phone Home: EDR Evasion Testing Reveals Extortion Actor's Toolkit</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list">

						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/sase/adem"   role="link" title="Autonomous Digital Experience Management" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager:SECURE ACCESS SERVICE EDGE:Prisma Access:Prisma SD-WAN:Autonomous Digital Experience Management">Autonomous Digital Experience Management</a>
						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/sase/next-gen-casb"   role="link" title="Cloud Access Security Broker" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager:SECURE ACCESS SERVICE EDGE:Prisma Access:Prisma SD-WAN:Autonomous Digital Experience Management:Cloud Access Security Broker">Cloud Access Security Broker</a>
						</li>

						</li>

          </button>
          <button class="modal__minimize-btn is-minimized">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
          </button>
          <button class="modal__close"> 
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/close-modal.svg" alt="Close button">
          </button>
          <video class="modal__video" id="customVideo">
            <source src="" type="video/mp4">Your browser does not support the video tag.
          </video>
          <div class="modal__post-details" tabindex="-1">       
              <h3>Default Heading</h3>
              <a class="l-btn" href="#" title="Right Arrow Icon" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="overview:explore reports:View all reports">Read the article
              <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow">
              </a>
          </div>
          <div class="modal__video-controls">
            <div class="modal__video-seekbar input__wrapper"><span></span>
              <label class="is-hidden" for="modalSeekBar">Seekbar</label>
              <input class="custom-range" id="modalSeekBar" type="range" min="0" max="100" value="1">
              <p class="modal__remaining-time"></p>
            </div>
            <button class="modal__play-btn is-paused" id="playPauseBtn">
            <img class="play" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-play-icon.svg" alt="Play">
            <img class="pause" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-pause-icon1.svg" alt="Pause">
          </button>
            <div class="modal__volume-controls">
              <div class="modal__volume__wrapper">
                <button tabindex="0">
                  <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-volume.svg" alt="Volume">
                </button>
                <div class="modal__volume-seekbar"><span></span>
                  <label class="is-hidden" for="volumeBar">Volume</label>
                  <input class="volume__bar" id="volumeBar" type="range" min="0" max="1" step="0.1" value="0.7">
                </div>
              </div>
              <button class="modal__minimize-btn" id="minimizeBtn">
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div><!--  End: video modal -->

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.7.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
